awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Documenting differences in gene expression during human tooth development to understand the evolution of the primate dentition
awd_abstract_narration:
Primate species, including humans, have diverse dental patterns that reflect different dietary and ecological specializations, but the genetic mechanisms that underlie these differences are poorly understood. The goal of this study is to identify specific genes that are responsible for tooth formation and tooth shape in humans and other primates. The investigators will use human and mouse dental tissues in conjunction with state-of-the-art molecular techniques to identify genes and measure differences in gene expression across tooth types (i.e. incisors, canines, premolars). The findings from this novel and potentially transformative study will not only advance science by informing research on dental evolution, but may have societal impact by contributing to the understanding and future treatment of dental malformations in humans. 

In this 24 month study, cutting-edge RNA sequencing technology will be used to quantify levels of expression of all genes at a key stage in human tooth development (cap stage), and to compare dental gene expression in humans and mice. Identifying individual genes that are the primary determinants of a tooth's cusp pattern will help explain how the human dentition is patterned during development and what dental genes have been conserved during mammalian evolution. This research will result in novel, testable hypotheses of how differences in gene expression may produce dental variation and adaptations seen in extinct and extant primate species. This represents a first step towards understanding evolutionary transitions that gave rise to the present dental diversity among primates because the genetic and developmental drivers of changes in tooth shape cannot be uncovered until the formation of differently shaped teeth is fully characterized. In addition, knowledge of the genetic components required for tooth formation will provide potentially transformative new information on the genetic underpinnings of anatomical anomalies in teeth. The project will also provide student training and scientific outreach, including a guided-inquiry lab in which undergraduate students will test hypotheses of the correspondence between tooth morphology, function, and diet in mammals and learn how differently-shaped teeth develop.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Properly formed teeth are important to the health and survival of many mammals, including humans. Tooth shape and the number of teeth in the dentition vary dramatically between different species of mammals, reflecting differences in dietary and ecological specializations. Despite their importance, the genetic basis for differences in tooth shape is poorly understood. The focus of this research is to document the genes responsible for the formation of differently-shaped teeth during mammalian embryonic development.

To better understand the development of the mammalian dentition, we examined gene expression in developing embryonic teeth in two mammal species, the laboratory mouse and the domestic cat, an emerging model organism in developmental biology. Cats, like humans and other primates, have a primary dentition that includes incisors, canines, and premolars therefore, the cat is a well-suited model for studying developmental differences between differently-shaped teeth. In contrast to cats, mice have just two types of teeth, incisors and molars, and they lack canines and premolars. Domestic cats have a more similar dentition to humans than mice, therefore the cat is a superior model compared to the laboratory mouse for determining genetic differences between different types of teeth (incisor, canine, premolar) that may be extended to the human dentition. The domestic cat is a relatively new model organism, therefore, we described in detail the main stages of tooth development in a series of cat embryos at different stages of development. Additionally, we used high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scanning to obtain three-dimensional images of embryonic cat teeth during development.

In a developing embryo, the formation of anatomically distinct structures is driven predominantly by differences in gene expression; some genes are highly active while others are less active or inactive. Using RNA sequencing of domestic cat teeth, we quantified levels of expression of genes within incisor, canine, and premolar teeth at a key stage in development. We identified over 200 genes that are expressed at different relative levels between incisor, canine, and premolar teeth. From the genes identified through RNA-sequencing, we selected a subset of genes for further analysis to determine the exact region(s) within developing teeth where these genes are active. Our results show that unique combinations of genes are expressed within incisor, canine, and premolar teeth at a single stage of development in domestic cat embryos.

To detect genetic differences specifically between incisors and molars, we compared spatial patterns of gene expression in teeth of laboratory mice at early, middle, and late stages of tooth development. Our results revealed spatial changes in the expression patterns of specific genes over the course of embryonic tooth development. Determining the time and place where specific genes are active within an embryo is fundamental to understanding how complex structures like teeth form during development.

Collectively this work represents a fundamental step towards understanding evolutionary transitions that have given rise to the present dental diversity within mammals because understanding genetic differences between developing teeth is a necessary pre-requisite to uncovering the genetic and developmental drivers of changes in tooth shape. Our study is unique because we examined gene expression in canines and premolars, two tooth types that are under-studied because the majority of work on dental development has focused on mice but mice lack canines and premolars. This study advances our knowledge of dental development by identifying specific genes that are important for the proper development of individual types of teeth, especially canine and premolar teeth because, prior to this study, little was known about the genetic basis for the development of these particular teeth. The wealth of genetic data generated from this project lays the foundation for future experiments testing the functional roles of specific genes in the development of differently-shaped teeth.

This project provided numerous opportunities for undergraduate and graduate student training in developmental and molecular biology. Additionally, during this project we generated comparative anatomy data sets for cat and mouse teeth at different stages of development which consist of two-dimensional images of histological cross-sections and three-dimensional renderings from CT scan data.  These images will be made freely available online for both research and educational purposes. Collectively, the photographs of these histological sections of cat and mouse teeth at different developmental stages comprise a comparative anatomical tooth atlas which students will be able to use to study and compare developing teeth from mice and cats, two ecologically distinct mammals with very different diets and dentitions.


Last Modified: 02/03/2019
Modified by: Emily Woodruff
